Award.AwardTitle: NUE: Development of a Minor in Nanotechnologies for Surface Engineering (Nano-SurfEng) - A Cross-Departmental Effort at Illinois Institute of Technology

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This NUE program at Illinois Institute of Technology (IIT) under the direction of Dr. Tongyan Pan, aims to develop an engineering minor: Nano Surface Engineering (Nano-SurfEng) to prepare undergraduate students for careers or graduate studies in surface processing and characterization of materials using modern nanotechnologies. The accomplishment of this objective entails integrating the state-of-the-art surface nanotechnologies into IIT's existing courses to develop a set of Nano-SurfEng curricula. Building on IIT?s core engineering courses, the targeted Nano-SurfEng curricula will include six new or redesigned lecture courses, one redesigned laboratory course, and one senior design project, to be created collectively by the four PIs from three different engineering disciplines in the Armour College of Engineering at IIT, i.e., Civil Engineering, Material Engineering, and Chemical and Biological Engineering. The Nano-SurfEng students will also have extensive research opportunities with the PIs or through internships with the numerous institutions, research laboratories, and companies in the Metro Chicago area.

The Nano-SurfEng Minor will support the development of the next generation of nanotechnology scientists and engineers through early, advanced scientific education at the undergraduate level. This minor will be the first nanotechnology-focused engineering discipline on IIT campus that will complement and strengthen the current well-established engineering disciplines at IIT. The Nano-SurfEng Minor targets 20 undergraduate students per year and its core courses will be open to the five engineering departments at IIT to benefit all the engineering students. The Nano-SurfEng Minor will bring extensive research opportunities in nanotechnologies with the four PIs and offer internship opportunities to all Nano-SurfEng students. A successful institutionalization of the Nano-SurfEng Minor will undoubtedly improve the education infrastructure at IIT. The resources and outcomes from this NUE effort will be disseminated to the public through the NSF nanoHUB, journal and conference publications, and a digital library of modern nanotechnologies. Developed course materials will be shared with the 23 members of the Association of Independent Technological Universities and other peer universities, and extended to local K-12 teachers and students via two outreach programs at IIT.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NUE project aims at developing a new engineering minor: Nano Surface Engineering (Nano-SurfEng) at Illinois Institute of Technology (IIT) to prepare 20 graduates per year for industrial careers or graduate studies in general nano-surface engineering. At the completion of the project, three major results were produced for the Nano-SurfEng Minor, including 1) eight courses in nano-surface engineering, 2) research opportunities for 20 undergraduate students per year with PIs or by internships, and 3) curricular materials and research results ready to reach out to K-12 groups, peer institutions, and engineering community. During the NUE project, the eight Nano-SurfEng courses were taught at IIT in the PIs’ and colleagues’ classes along with the student-research and outreach activities. More than 300 undergraduate engineering students attended the Nano-SurfEng courses. The PIs offered extensive research opportunities to undergraduate students at IIT related to general nanotechnologies and modern microscopy and spectroscopy in their research laboratories. A total of 50 undergraduate engineering students worked in PIs’ laboratories and the research laboratories of the governmental agencies and companies in the greater Chicago area in the two-year project duration. During the NUE project, outcomes including curricular materials, students’ research results, and PIs’ intellectual products were disseminated to local high schools, presented at engineering expo events and conferences, and published in professional journals. A total of six journal publications were produced based on this NUE project.

Intellectual merit: The hierarchically structured nano-surface engineering courses inspired interests among students to pursue careers and advanced degrees in the nanotechnologies. Furthermore, the exposure of undergraduate students to modern nanotechnologies fostered the development of new nano-instruments or creation of new nanotechnologies. More broadly, as nanoscale surface analysis is becoming a core technology in many research and development disciplines today, this Nano-SurfEng Minor will continue contributing to the development of qualified nanotechnology workforce to meet the great needs. From this perspective, this innovative engineering program has far-reaching technological impacts in the future to benefit multiple aspects of modern research and development sectors.

Broader impacts: The PIs also made efforts in broadening the participation of female, Black and Hispanic groups in surface engineering and nanotechnologies. The NUE project engaged female and minority faculty in nanotechnology undergraduate education and attracted K-12 students via outreach channels. The established Nano-SurfEng minor can be expected to improve the awareness of modern technologies among underrepresented groups, positively affect their daily lives and social actions, and eventually achieve the equal development of all ethnic groups.
